attribs.name: personality_traits
attribs.current: I love a good insult, even one directed at me.

attribs.name: ideals
attribs.current: Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)

attribs.name: bonds
attribs.current: I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.

attribs.name: flaws
attribs.current: I'll do anything to win fame and renown.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4ICOOahBbOeatktRUo_description
attribs.current: Since you come from the ranks of the common folk, you fit in among them with ease. You can find a place to hide, rest, or recuperate among other commoners, unless you have shown yourself to be a danger to them. They will shield you from the law or anyone else searching for you, though they will not risk their lives for you. [In places that you have won in]

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4ICoghnlFCSx7L9PU3_description
attribs.current:
Starting at 3rd level, your mastery as a rider becomes apparent. You have advantage on saving throws made to avoid falling off your mount. If you fall off your mount and descend no more than 10 feet, you can land on your feet if you're not incapacitated.

Finally, mounting or dismounting a creature costs you only 5 feet of movement, rather than half your speed.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4ICogr439dOiIrePIs_description
attribs.current:
Starting at 3rd level, you can menace your foes, foiling their attacks and punishing them for harming others. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can mark the creature until the end of your next turn. This effect ends early if you are incapacitated or you die, or if someone else marks the creature.

While it is within 5 feet of you, a creature marked by you has disadvantage on any attack roll that doesn't target you.

In addition, if a creature marked by you deals damage to anyone other than you, you can make a special melee weapon attack against the marked creature as a bonus action on your next turn. You have advantage on the attack roll, and if it hits, the attack's weapon deals extra damage to the target equal to half your fighter level.

Regardless of the number of creatures you mark, you can make this special attack a number of times equal to your Strength modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4ICpPby10-I-6mXcKM_description
attribs.current:
You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4ICpPt-fgBbJC0XFLE_description
attribs.current:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4IjcDRdyyonvM0SEJB_description
attribs.current:
When angered, you radiate menace. You gain the following benefits:

- Increase your Strength, Constitution, or Charisma by 1, to a maximum of 20.

- Instead of exhaling destructive energy, you can expend a use of your Breath Weapon trait to roar, forcing each creature of your choice within 30 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier). A target automatically succeeds on the save if it can't hear or see you. On a failed save, a target becomes frightened of you for 1 minute. If the frightened target takes any damage, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

attribs.name: character_appearance
attribs.current:
His face is heavily scarred, with two large, pale horns protruding from the back of his head. From the back of his head down to his tail are an array of bone-white spikes. His back is scarred from years of physical abuse.

His casual wear consists of white, poofy harem trousers or whatever those are called. No shirt, no shoes. He likes wearing bracelets.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M4IkmnGkm72Aez6t1rT_description
attribs.current:
Use your action to fire lightning in a 5x30 ft. line. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. The DC is 8 + CON + Prof. A creature takes 2d6 lightning damage on a failed save, half as much on a success.

After you use your breath weapon, you can't use it again until you rest.

Damage increases to 3d6 at 6th level, 4d6 at 11th level, and 5d6 at 16th level.

attribs.name: character_backstory
attribs.current:
Here's the scoop: Kalrin sold himself into a life of slavery when he was a kid. It wasn't a smart decision, but it was one he felt he had to make to support his family. Though, his family never really mattered to him in the first place, so it was a pretty dumb move. Eventually Kalrin had the opportunity to fight for his freedom, and so he took it. By pure chance, Kalrin was able to fight his way through strong fighters and monsters until he accrued enough of a reputation to earn his freedom. There was a catch however, and his "freedom" entailed more prizefighting, though now he was subservient to a stingy deep gnome called Cricket. The "partnership"  between Cricket and Kalrin started out with promise, as Kalrin was living on his estate for the time being, which certainly beat the slave pens. It only took a few jobs before their relationship soured and Cricket's vile and abusive personality came to fruition [Lawful Evil]. And so he ran! An escape from the planet of the apes! Kalrin fled the scene never to fight for Cricket again. 

Kalrin aspires to be a great hero who can find people worth protecting. 

He is looking for a new quest that can bring him fame, and he doesn't sweat the details.

He doesn't mind pit fighting and in fact he often indulges in it when his funds are looking low.

attribs.name: repeating_spell-9_-M4WNcGNwOZCfaTm6WF3_spelldescription
attribs.current: You utter a word of power that can compel one creature you can see within range to die instantly. If the creature you choose has 100 hit points or fewer, it dies. Otherwise, the spell has no effect.

attribs.name: allies_and_organizations
attribs.current:
Bio stuff:
Family: 
{ 
   Mother: Asathra Koff
        Occupation: Trapper
    Father: Shedinn Koff (deceased)
        Occupation: Adventurer (Wizard)
    Siblings:
        2 brothers (twins): Adrex, Adrynnicus
}

Prior Connections:
{
    Cricket: A deep gnome who is absolutely rolling in the dough. He is the head of a shady syndicate in Sho-Battai and is pretty heavily invested in local prizefighting.

    Goblins: In his many years as a slave Kalrin found some goblinoid friends who he learned the language from.
}
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Runner's Retreat: A small desert outpost, the starting town :D. It's led by a council of commerce (or something like that). There's a ranger's outpost in town and they have access to clean water.
{
    Coran: Our initial contact. A treasure hunter who was in search of an ancient sword in a tomb some ways off from Runner's Retreat. We helped him retrieve the sword but he almost died, and lost his hand.
    Rotrick Mormundd and the Sword: Some old dwarven(?) man whose soul is trapped in an ancient blade. He possesses the wielder of the sword and tries to kill anyone he sees.
    Steele: Coran's rival. He's not very evil and mostly makes empty threats, he doesn't seem too bad and is open to us working with him in the future. We can find him in Mithril, because he's actually the leader of Mithril.
    Jenaul: Dwarven female, head of the council in Runner's Retreat.
    Karas: Human male, colorful artist man.
    Wilyn: Elderly halfling man.
    Tarnor: Macho half-orc man.
    Daenon: A ranger we found in the Rhosus crypt in suspended animation. We brought him to the ranger outpost in runner's retreat, and Jordip gave us some magic gear in return.
    Jordip: A gnome who works as an alchemist for the rangers.
}

Wellsford: Sketchy place man, everyone is "nice" but they seem to mostly serve some cult (at least some of them). The cult of Rhostus.
{
    Fern: Hospitable man, let us stay in wellsford. Acting leader of the town.
    Elsie: Nice lady, Fern's sister. Good cook!
    Cult of Rhostus: For the most part, weak cultists in servitude to Rhostus. They reside in the crypt behind Wellsford. They wear red robes and have a recognizable symbol. We found some people in stasis in the crypt, and took two of them back to runner's retreat.
    Rhostus (killed by party): An evil descended minor god of knowledge who is trying to return to the pantheon. He's been stripped of his mortal body and exists only as a brain. He retains only a fraction of his psionic ability. He really wanted to consume Fane's knowledge.
}

Axe: Militaristic encampment that threatens Wellsford. Wellsford gives them ale just so they don't get destroyed. Populated mostly by goblins, the village serves the Battle Lord (Maglubiyet) and often holds ceremonial sacrifices in the form of battle. (They also stole a freaking elephant).
{
    Neck: Leader of Axe, elven fighter/gladiator man. Pretty respectable honestly.
}

Mithril: 
{
    Mining city north of runner's retreat, led by Copernicus Steele.
}

Grimgnash: Young Blue Dragon, wizard battled him, the blue dragon crumbled his lair to try and kill him, but the wizard survived. The party had no choice but to agree to serve Grimgnash, but he has yet to enforce any work on us. He wants us to find the wizard's tower.

attribs.name: repeating_traits_-M6DDt8Jy2eTJ4Mueonn_description
attribs.current:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.
